title: ConfigMaps
description: Store non-confidential configuration data as key-value pairs.
code:
# configmap.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: app-config
data:
  database_url: "postgres://db:5432/mydb"
  log_level: "info"
  app.properties: |
    app.name=MyApp
    app.version=1.0
    app.port=8080
command:
# Create ConfigMap from file
kubectl create configmap app-config --from-file=config.properties

# Create from literal values
kubectl create configmap app-config \
  --from-literal=database_url=postgres://db:5432 \
  --from-literal=log_level=info

# Get ConfigMaps
kubectl get configmaps
kubectl get cm

# Describe ConfigMap
kubectl describe configmap app-config

# View ConfigMap data
kubectl get configmap app-config -o yaml

# Delete ConfigMap
kubectl delete configmap app-config
example:
# Use ConfigMap as environment variables
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: myapp
spec:
  containers:
  - name: app
    image: myapp:latest
    envFrom:
    - configMapRef:
        name: app-config

# Use specific keys from ConfigMap
env:
- name: DATABASE_URL
  valueFrom:
    configMapKeyRef:
      name: app-config
      key: database_url

# Mount ConfigMap as volume
volumes:
- name: config
  configMap:
    name: app-config
volumeMounts:
- name: config
  mountPath: /etc/config
useCase: Application configuration, environment-specific settings, feature flags

interviewQuestions.question: What is the difference between ConfigMap and Secret?
interviewQuestions.answer: ConfigMap: non-sensitive config data, stored plain text. Secret: sensitive data, base64 encoded (not encrypted!), needs RBAC protection. Both: 1MB limit, consumed same way (env/volume). Use Secret for passwords, ConfigMap for app settings.

interviewQuestions.question: Tricky: You update ConfigMap used by running pod. Does pod see new values?
interviewQuestions.answer: Depends on consumption method. Env vars: NO (pod needs restart). Volume mount: YES (after sync delay ~60s). Use envFrom with configMapRef for env – manual pod restart or rolling update needed.

interviewQuestions.question: Output: kubectl create configmap myconf --from-file=app.properties. What is the key name?
interviewQuestions.answer: Key name is 'app.properties' (filename). Access as configMapKeyRef: {name: myconf, key: app.properties}. Use --from-file=customkey=app.properties to set custom key name.

interviewQuestions.question: What happens if ConfigMap referenced in pod doesn't exist?
interviewQuestions.answer: Pod stuck in Pending/CreateContainerConfigError. Use optional: true in configMapKeyRef to make it optional. Pod will start without it. Check: kubectl describe pod shows event missing ConfigMap.

interviewQuestions.question: How do you create ConfigMap from multiple files in directory?
interviewQuestions.answer: kubectl create configmap myconf --from-file=./config-dir/ creates keys for each file. Or --from-env-file for KEY=VALUE format. Each file becomes separate key in ConfigMap.

interviewQuestions.question: Predict: ConfigMap has key 'log-level'. How to use as env var LOG_LEVEL?
interviewQuestions.answer:
env:
- name: LOG_LEVEL
  valueFrom:
    configMapKeyRef:
      name: myconfig
      key: log-level
Note: key can have hyphens, env var name typically underscores.

interviewQuestions.question: What is an immutable ConfigMap and why use it?
interviewQuestions.answer: immutable: true prevents changes, provides performance benefits (apiserver doesn't watch), protects production config. Once set, cannot modify – must delete and recreate. Available from K8s v1.19.

interviewQuestions.question: Tricky: Can ConfigMap be in namespace A and pod in namespace B?
interviewQuestions.answer: No! ConfigMap and Pod must be in same namespace. Cross-namespace referencing not allowed. Duplicate ConfigMap in each namespace or use external config management.

interviewQuestions.question: What's the size limit for ConfigMap and what happens if exceeded?
interviewQuestions.answer: 1MB limit. kubectl create fails with 'request entity too large'. Split into multiple ConfigMaps or use external config store (etcd, Consul, cloud secret managers). etcd has 1MB object limit.

interviewQuestions.question: How do you update all pods using ConfigMap after config change?
interviewQuestions.answer: If using env: manual restart or rolling update (kubectl rollout restart deployment). If using volume: auto-updates after ~60s. Or: use config hash in deployment annotation to trigger auto-rollout.

exercises.question: Create ConfigMap from literal app=myapp version=1.0
Create ConfigMap from file config.json and verify data
exercises.answer: kubectl create configmap fileconf --from-file=config.json && kubectl get cm fileconf -o yaml

exercises.question: ConfigMap mounted as volume updates. How long for pods to see new values?
exercises.answer: ~60 seconds (configmap sync period). Can configure with --sync-frequency flag on kubelet.

exercises.question: Pod shows CreateContainerConfigError. Where to check?
exercises.answer: kubectl describe pod (Events section shows missing ConfigMap/Secret). Verify ConfigMap exists: kubectl get cm. Check namespace matches.

exercises.question: Can you base64 encode data in ConfigMap like Secret?
exercises.answer: Yes, manually encode but not automatic. ConfigMap stores whatever you give it. However, no special handling – just plain text storage.

exercises.question: Extract value of key 'database' from ConfigMap 'dbconf'
Create immutable ConfigMap
exercises.answer: Add immutable: true in spec when creating. Or: kubectl create configmap myconf --from-literal=key=value --dry-run=client -o yaml | sed 's/metadata:/&\n  immutable: true/' | kubectl apply -f -

exercises.question: ConfigMap changed but pod still using old values (env vars). Fix?
exercises.answer: Env vars don't auto-update. Solution: kubectl rollout restart deployment/myapp to recreate pods with new values.

exercises.question: Create ConfigMap from all files in directory ./configs/
kubectl create cm test --from-literal=KEY=value. What is stored in etcd?
exercises.answer: Plain text 'value'. ConfigMaps are NOT encrypted in etcd by default. Need encryption at rest configuration for security.

programExercises.question: Program 1: Create ConfigMap, use as env vars in pod
programExercises.code:
kubectl create configmap app-env --from-literal=APP_ENV=production --from-literal=LOG_LEVEL=debug
kubectl run testpod --image=busybox --restart=Never --dry-run=client -o yaml > pod.yaml
# Edit pod.yaml to add envFrom configMapRef
kubectl apply -f pod.yaml
kubectl exec testpod -- env | grep -E 'APP_ENV|LOG_LEVEL'

programExercises.question: Program 2: Mount ConfigMap as volume, verify file contents
programExercises.code:
kubectl create configmap vol-config --from-literal=config.txt='Hello from ConfigMap'
kubectl run volpod --image=nginx --dry-run=client -o yaml > volpod.yaml
# Edit to add volume mount
kubectl apply -f volpod.yaml
kubectl exec volpod -- cat /etc/config/config.txt

programExercises.question: Program 3: Create from file, update it, observe volume mount change
programExercises.code:
echo 'version=1.0' > app.conf
kubectl create configmap appconf --from-file=app.conf
kubectl run app --image=nginx --dry-run=client -o yaml > app.yaml
# Add volume mount /etc/config
kubectl apply -f app.yaml
kubectl exec app -- cat /etc/config/app.conf
# Update
echo 'version=2.0' > app.conf
kubectl create configmap appconf --from-file=app.conf --dry-run=client -o yaml | kubectl apply -f -
sleep 65
kubectl exec app -- cat /etc/config/app.conf

programExercises.question: Program 4: Test missing ConfigMap causes CreateContainerConfigError
programExercises.code:
kubectl run badpod --image=nginx --dry-run=client -o yaml > bad.yaml
# Edit to reference non-existent configmap
kubectl apply -f bad.yaml
kubectl get pod badpod
kubectl describe pod badpod | grep Error
programExercises.output: Pod stuck, CreateContainerConfigError: configmap not found

programExercises.question: Program 5: Create ConfigMap from directory with multiple files
programExercises.code:
mkdir configs
echo 'db=postgres' > configs/database.conf
echo 'cache=redis' > configs/cache.conf
kubectl create configmap multiconf --from-file=configs/
kubectl get cm multiconf -o yaml
programExercises.output: Shows data with keys database.conf and cache.conf

programExercises.question: Program 6: Extract all keys from ConfigMap
programExercises.code: kubectl create configmap sample --from-literal=key1=val1 --from-literal=key2=val2\nkubectl get configmap sample -o jsonpath='{.data}' | jq 'keys'

programExercises.question: Program 7: Test envFrom loads all keys as environment variables
programExercises.code:
kubectl create configmap allenv --from-literal=DB_HOST=localhost --from-literal=DB_PORT=5432
kubectl run envpod --image=busybox --restart=Never --dry-run=client -o yaml > env.yaml
# Add envFrom with configMapRef
kubectl apply -f env.yaml
kubectl exec envpod -- env | grep DB_
